paper.title: Apply algebraic methods in solving problems
paper.instructions: Calculators are not permitted in this examination. Show all working. Write your answers in the spaces provided.

parts.text: Solve the equation: 4(2x - 3) + 5x = 27.
Solve the inequality: 3x + 7 > 22.
The line y = 2x - 4 intersects the x-axis at point A. Find the coordinates of A.
Factorise: x² + 7x + 12 = 0.
Solve using the quadratic formula: 3x² - 2x - 2 = 0.
The discriminant of ax² + bx + c = 0 is 25. If a = 1 and b = -6, find c.
Solve the system: 2x + y = 7, x - 3y = -8.
An arithmetic sequence has first term 5 and common difference 3. Find the 10th term.
The sum of the first n terms of a sequence is S_n = n² + n. Find the 4th term.
Sketch the graph of y = x² - 4x + 3, showing intercepts and vertex.
The graph of y = f(x) is transformed to y = 2f(x - 1) + 3. Describe the transformations.
parts.answer: Horizontal shift right 1 unit, vertical stretch by factor 2, vertical shift up 3 units

parts.text: Find the equation of the line parallel to y = 3x - 2 passing through (1, 5).
A rectangle has length (x + 4) cm and width (2x - 1) cm. The perimeter is 50 cm. Solve for x.
Diagram: Right-angled triangle with opposite side 5 cm to angle θ, hypotenuse 13 cm. Find sin θ.
Hence find the adjacent side.

paper.title: Investigate relationships between tables, equations and graphs
paper.instructions: Show all working. Write your answers in the spaces provided.

parts.text: Find the equation of a line passing through given points.
parts.reasoning: Correct equation found using gradient and y-intercept

parts.text: Write the equation after transforming y = -7/2 x - 3 with given shifts.
parts.reasoning: Vertical shift and/or horizontal shift applied correctly

parts.text: Three players (Anne, Ben, Charlie) have health points over time in a game. Anne: linear decrease from 4000, loses 500 per minute. Ben: exponential decay from 12000, halves each minute. Charlie: quadratic relationship starting at 12250, finishing at 7 minutes. Find equations, create table and graphs, and make comments about the game.
parts.reasoning: Anne has linear decay. Ben has exponential decay (halving). Charlie has quadratic. Key observations: Anne and Ben both have 3000 at 2 minutes. Charlie finishes first at 7 minutes, Anne at 8 minutes. Ben plays longest (9+ minutes), still has ~23.44 points when time runs out. Charlie leads for most of game but loses first.
comments: Anne and Ben both have 3000 after 2 minutes
Anne and Charlie both have approx. 585 after approx. 6.8 minutes
Charlie finishes first (7 minutes), then Anne (8 minutes), Ben lasts 9+ minutes
Ben still has some left (approx. 23.44) when time runs out after 9 minutes
Charlie is in the lead for most of the game but loses first

parts.text: Draw the graph of an exponential function y = 2^x showing accuracy through points (-1, 2), (0, 4), (1, 8), (2, 16), (3, 32).
parts.reasoning: Exponential growth curve drawn accurately

parts.text: Find the x-coordinate of the vertex and the depth (y-value) of a parabola representing a hole.
parts.reasoning: Vertex found at x = 2.5, minimum y-value is -1.8 m below surface

parts.text: Make two valid comments about how to make the hole less deep by changing the quadratic equation.
parts.reasoning: Sample comments: (1) Reducing the coefficient of 0.8 will make the hole less deep/steep. (2) Changing intercepts closer together e.g. y = 0.8(x-1)(x-2) makes hole shallower. (3) Adding positive number < 1.8 to end of equation makes hole less deep.
comments: Reducing the coefficient of 0.8 will make the hole less deep (or less steep)
Changing the intercepts so they are closer together will make the hole shallower
Adding a positive number < 1.8 to the end of the equation will make the hole less deep

parts.text: Find the equation of an exponential curve shown in a graph.
parts.reasoning: Exponential decay function identified

parts.text: A hole has equation related to y = 0.125(x - 5)² - 2.5. Water surface is at y = -2. Find the width of the hole at water level.
parts.reasoning: Solve -2 = 0.125(x - 5)² - 2.5. Get 0.5 = 0.125(x - 5)², so 4 = (x - 5)², giving x = 7 or x = 3. Width = 7 - 3 = 4 metres. Alternative: expand to y = 0.125x² - 1.25x + 0.625, solve -2 = 0.125x² - 1.25x + 0.625 to get x = 3 or x = 7.

parts.text: Find the equation of a parabola with given properties (vertex or factored form).
parts.reasoning: Quadratic equation found in vertex form, factored form, or expanded form

parts.text: Find T values when n = 4 and n = 5 from a pattern sequence.
parts.reasoning: Both T-values required from the pattern

parts.text: Find the formula for the sequence pattern.
parts.reasoning: Quadratic formula identified with correct coefficients

parts.text: Draw a graph of the sequence for 1 ≤ n ≤ 8 showing discrete values only.
parts.answer: Graph with discrete points (dots) for integer values only, no negative values, not a continuous line
parts.reasoning: Graph should show only integer value dots (discrete values) for positive n values according to context

parts.text: Lizzy has a 60 cm stick to cut into two pieces to form a rectangle. Investigate the relationship between lengths and area. Create table, graph, and equation, and make comments about maximum area and patterns.
parts.latex: \text{Area} = x(60 - x) \quad \text{where } x \text{ is length of first piece}
parts.answer: Area = x(60 - x). Maximum area = 900 cm² when both lengths are 30 cm
parts.reasoning: Table showing relationship between lengths (x and 60-x) and area. Graph is continuous parabola. Area formula is quadratic. Key observations: Maximum 900 cm² at x = 30. Graph/area is symmetrical. Minimum area is 0 cm². Rate of increase changes for different x-values. Graph is continuous as all x-values possible with accurate measurement. In reality, some x-values close to 0 or 60 may be impossible to cut. As the two sides get closer in length, area increases.
comments: Maximum area is 900 cm² when both lengths are 30 cm
Graph and area size is symmetrical
Rate of increase of the area changes for different x-values
The graph will be continuous as all different x-values are possible with accurate measurements
In reality, some x-values close to 0 or close to 60 are likely impossible for Lizzy to cut
As the two sides of the rectangle get closer together in length, the area increases

paper.title: Apply geometric reasoning in solving problems
paper.instructions: Show all working. Write your answers in the spaces provided.

questions.topic: Angles, parallel lines, trigonometry and similar triangles

parts.text: Find the value of x (angle AGB), given that angle AED = 58° in a triangle, and lines are parallel.
parts.reasoning: ∠AED = 58° (angles in triangle add to 180°), x = ∠AGB = 58° (corresponding angles, parallel lines)

parts.text: Calculate the area of triangle AHE, where the base is 4 m and angle is 46°. Use EK = 2.8 × tan 46°.
parts.reasoning: EK = 2.8 × tan 46° = 2.8995 m (height), Area = ½ × base × height

parts.text: Two similar triangular sails P and Q have bases 3.6 m and 1.44 m respectively. Triangle P has side length 6 m. Calculate total sail area and determine if sails are big enough for top speed (need 12 m²).
parts.answer: Total sail area = 11.95 m². Sails are not big enough for top speed.
parts.reasoning: Triangles similar (AAA rule). Ratio = 2.5. Height P = 5.724 m, height Q = 2.289 m. Area P = 10.303 m², Area Q = 1.648 m². Total = 11.95 m² < 12 m²

parts.text: Navigation problem: Find bearing from M to S using triangle with sides 448 km (angle 36°) and 635 km (angle 66°).
Show that h = 6.32 m using Pythagoras theorem, given hypotenuse 8 m and base 4.9 m.
parts.reasoning: Using Pythagoras: h² = 8² - 4.9² = 64 - 24.01 = 39.99, so h = 6.32 m

parts.text: Find length g = PQ, where MQ and MP are calculated using Pythagoras. Given MQ uses height 6.32 m and hypotenuse 11 m.
Find the perimeter of a shape involving triangle MPN with angle 52.2° and side 4.9 m.
Prove that ∠SAG = ∠AHG = ∠GBA = p using circle theorems (tangent-radius, angle in semicircle, angles in same segment).
parts.reasoning: ∠SAH = 90° (tangent ⊥ radius). ∠AGH = 90° (angle in semicircle). ∠GAH = 90° - p. Therefore ∠GHA = p. ∠GBA = ∠GHA = p (angles in same segment). Alternatively: use alternate segment theorem.

parts.text: Find angle q = ∠VRS using circle theorems. Given ∠VRU base angle is 71° and ∠URT = 38°.
parts.reasoning: ∠VRU = (180° - 38°)/2 = 71° (base angle of isosceles triangle). ∠URT = 38° (from part i or alternate segment). ∠VRS = q = 180° - 71° - 38° = 71°

questions.topic: Angle properties, tangent-radius, cyclic quadrilaterals and regular polygons

parts.text: Find ∠MEB given that ∠EBM = 58° (alternate angles, parallel lines) and triangle is isosceles.
parts.reasoning: ∠EBM = 58° (alternate angles, parallel lines). ∠EMB = 58° (base angles of isosceles triangle). ∠MEB = 180° - 58° - 58° = 64°

parts.text: Find length LC where ∠CML = 90° (tangent-radius), ∠MLN is bisected giving ∠MLCe = 36°, and CL is opposite the 36° angle with adjacent side 28 mm.
parts.reasoning: ∠CML = 90° (tangent ⊥ radius), so triangle CML is right-angled. ∠MLR = 36° (bisecting ∠MLN). Using sine: LC = 28/sin 36° = 47.64 mm

parts.text: Find ∠DBA in terms of x, where ∠DAB = x, using angle in semicircle and cyclic quadrilateral properties.
parts.reasoning: ∠DEB = 90° (angle in semicircle). ∠EAB = 180° - x (opposite angles of cyclic quad). ∠DBE = 90° - x (angle sum of triangle). ∠ABE = x/2 (base angles of isosceles). ∠DBA = 90° - x + x/2 = 90° - x/2

parts.text: Find expression for total area of regular octagon with vertices on circle radius r, where internal angle is 135°.
parts.reasoning: ∠PNM = 135° (internal angle). ∠CNM = 67.5° (symmetry). CZ = r sin 67.5° = 0.9239r, NZ = r cos 67.5° = 0.3827r. Area of one triangle = 0.3536r². Total = 8 × 0.3536r² = 2.8285r²
